original_title: A Digital Camera For The 1984 Market
original_content:
Digital cameras are a ubiquitous consumer and professional product here in 2023, and because of the wide availability of parts its relatively straightforward to construct one for yourself. Four decades ago though, film was king, but that hasnt stopped [Georg Lukas] from building a digital camera for the 1984 market. The hardware is definitely from recent years, the extremely affordable ESP32-cam board that many of us will have worked with already. Meanwhile the 1984 part lies in the recording format, it makes EGA 16-colour low-res pictures and stores them in the archaic TGA file format.
A low-res camera is fun, but there are two other angles on this which are definitely worth some time. The first is that his description and code are worth a read for anyone with an interest in programming an ESP32 camera, while the second invites us to consider whether such a camera could have been made using parts available in 1984. We remember camera peripherals for 8-bit microcomputers which were a C-mount lens positioned over a decapped RAM chip, and thus we cant help wondering whether an RGB split to three of those sensors could have been constructed. Whether a 6502 or a Z80 with 64k of memory could have processed the three images into one is another matter, but at least if any of you want to try theres a handy 1984 computer still popping up on eBay.
title: 1984年のマーケット向けに作られたデジタルカメラの製作方法
body: 2023年の今、デジタルカメラは一般の人々やプロに普及しており、パーツの入手が容易なため自分で作ることも簡単です。しかし、1984年の市場向けにデジタルカメラを作るために[Georg Lukas]が頑張りました。ハードウェアは最新のESP32-camボードで、1984年の部分はEGA 16色の低解像度の写真を撮り、古いTGAファイル形式で保存します。彼の説明とコードはESP32カメラのプログラミングに興味のある人に読む価値があります。また、1984年当時のパーツを使用してこのようなカメラを作ることができたのかも考えてみましょう。
